awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Workshop: Integrated Design of Active Dynamic Systems (IDADS); Champaign, Illinois
awd_abstract_narration:
This workshop will provide travel support for 50 participants, many of which are from under-represented groups, the opportunity to explore the state-of-the-art, knowledge gaps, practice, and future research directions for the integrated design and control of active systems. The workshop will consist of three sections, each of which consists of two plenary talks followed by a breakout session. Each section will address one of three critical topics in the integrated design and control of active systems: 1) State-of-the-Art and Fundamental Knowledge Gaps in Active System Design, 2) Moving Active System Design Optimization Tools toward Practical Utility, and 3) Defining Future Scientific Strategies for Active System Design. The breakout sessions will consist of five groups of 10 heterogeneous researchers that will address questions related to each topic. Each group will produce a written report of their conversations, a Slack workspace will be created for open conversation of all participants throughout and after the workshop, and the workshop organizers will write a final report.

This workshop will lead to the creation of a convergent group of researchers that combine expertise in the integrated design and control of active systems. This group will be well-situated to address the fundamental questions at the intersection of design and controls, and to create the methods and toolsets necessary to translate the theory to practice for a wide range of important applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the last several years, the desire for simultaneous optimization of physical systems and their controllers, termed control co-design, has been amplified in the energy, aerospace, and robotics industries, to name a few. Yet, while underlying theoretical formulations for control co-design exist, they utilize a disparate set of underlying assumptions and definitions (particularly based on whether the methodologies come from the design optimization or control communities), while often falling short of satisfying the needs of real engineering applications. The workshop and corresponding meetups enabled by this project have enabled academic and industry stateholders from both the design optimization and control communities to come together to define common terminology, problems, and forward-looking solutions for the control co-design community. These objectives were satisfied through several mechanisms. First, a virtual control co-design workshop was held in March of 2020, which replaced the originally planned in-person workshop. The virtual workshop was attended by over 80 participants and helped to identify key knowledge gaps, standardization gaps, future questions, and potential future approaches in the community. Because the COVID pandemic prevented an initial in-person workshop, the project team utilized additional available support to plan several hybrid in-person/virtual events as follow-ups to the initial workshop. Most notably, these included an energy-themed control co-design meetup at the University of Colorado at Boulder in May of 2022. Finally, as a result of this effort, PI Vermillion at NC State is working alongside PI Allison at the University of Illinois to organize an in-person event in 2023.

The intellectual merit of the workshop activities lies in the standardization of definitions, assumptions, and approaches across the co-design community, along with the definition of critical forward-looking research questions. These research questions, as identified through the workshops, involve consideration of robustness within co-design formulations, consideration of environmental variables in addition to plant and control variables, and the formal incorporation of experiments within co-design approaches. Broader impacts relate to the societal stakeholders that stand to benefit the most from the simultaneous consideration of both the physical system and controller in design. Perhaps most immediately relevantly, the renewable energy industry (for which many academic/industry teams are presently utilizing control co-design approaches for wind and marine energy that stand to benefit from the results of these workshops) will realize clear benefits from co-design approaches, which will allow technologies to reach the market faster (as is necessary, given the urgency of addressing global climate change) and yield better performance (which will translate to lower costs of energy and higher efficiencies).

Modified by: Christopher R Vermillion
